I don't blame Jeffree for feeling that way about You Tube. I think the essence of what You Tube used to be has been sucked out. I don't think it's big channels like Jeffree feeling like this. I think small channels and new channels would get the brunt of this unless they really stand out (from what I observe...I can think of two ASMR and one history related channel gaining a lot of traction despite being on You Tube not long). I'm a small channel and been on here for four years. You Tube has made it hard to get monetized and when I started, in order to get monetized...you needed a thousand subscribers and four thousand watch hours within twelve months. Problem? Most people that watch You Tube aren't the type of people who can subscribe to channels. Even a lot of bigger channels notice that the majority of the viewers are non-subscribers. Most of my views (as I have at least three vids that have over a thousand viewes) are non-subscribers. However, you can't get people to come to your channel if you're small because the algorithem picks up vids with a lot of views and likes because they are usually from bigger channels or channels owned by companies/celebrities. Even if you let people know about your vids off of You Tube...it doesn't get a lot of views. And the thing that is annoying now is that You Tube started putting ads on vids of smaller channels (like mine)...but yet you don't get one damn dime even if your vid. So, my excitement with having a channel has dwindled in the last two years. Not that I aim to be monetize, but when you don't get the views...it takes out the excitement you have of creating videos. Hence, I decided to go back to college at forty and get a degree associated with disaster preparedness as that's the field I want to work in. And hopefully doing that, make vids based on that (I've done some already for the fun of it)

Spider Fact: Although most people are under the impression that all spiders are venomous... Uloboridae are a family of spiders which have no venom glands at all. These spiders religh upon wrapping their prey quickly in silk. Once the prey is subdued, Uloboridae regurgitate digestive enzymes which then dissolve the victim into liquid food.

This fucked me up a bit. I hope jeffree knows how much people still watch. I binge yalls videos all the time. This series goes beyond the last 2.
Unfortunately to an extent Jeffery is right, what made YouTube the most popular thing has been fizzling down for the last couple years because of streaming - people use to have to make more of a choice of just wating to see what was on TV/Cable, if nothing good turn to YouTube and the limited streaming offerings. Covid hits and streaming took off bigtime. People aren't just clicking in for one-off videos, people either just want to speed thru tictocs / shorts and move on. OR they want series type content. Even then people want to binge watch thru and do a one and done sitting, less patience to sit and wait week to week for new videos (or tv episodes). Its all about instant gratification. And when they do watch a video they want the content to carry over to the next one or have videos/episodes cram in as much as possible into a longer form video, no more 12min and dones. The trouble is content creator don't want to risk/can't afford to put in a shit ton of work, money and effort into an hour long video if it isn't going to draw a few million views right off the bat, the window to make money is super short and if there isn't a sponsor, forget about it.   Hell, Matt Damon did an episode of Hot Ones and explained how the shift from DVD sales to streaming has killed how movies are made/the kind of movies studios will put money towards, because they can't make their money back without physical sales. and to an extent it is the same thing that's happening to YouTube, money has shifted, people can just stream shows and movies so they don't need YouTube content like they use to.  I still come on every day for stuff to watch - mostly listen to, there are content creators I love and can't wait to see each and every new vid. And I've noticed a LOT of the content creators I use to follow have been disappearing over the last two - three years. It sucks, but it's a reallity. Some have thankfully shifted to more podcast content to fill in the gaps in posting so I can still get some of their content, but many have just said enough is enough and dipped out of content creation all together because their content can't adapt to new media - painters/sculptors can't really thrive in a non-visual media.  Will it suck to see Jeffery cut out YouTube, yes, (I don't have TicTok) so there's one less creator to watch. But he seems soooooo much happier now, so good for him. Be happy in what makes him happy.
